trial_identification.studytitle: HELP-AF: A randomised controlled trial assessing Home-based Education and Learning Program for Atrial Fibrillation
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In AF patients who present to the Emergency Department does the addition of a home-based learning and education package improve quality of life and reduce re-hospitalisation.

interventions.interventions: Home-based Education and Learning Package: 2 x Home visits (1-1.5 hrs in duration). Featuring clinical characterization and delivery of information using Structured Educational Visiting techniques via a trained allied health professionals at 1-2 and 7-8 weeks after enrollment. Main education principle will be to encourage the patient to become a participant in their AF specific health care rather than a passive 'passenger'. The intervention will include printed educational material, a personal action plan, and access to advice via an emergency phone line. The action plan will be completed in collaboration with the patient's GP/cardiologist.
interventions.comparator: Usual Care - Patient education is expected to be provided in an ad-hoc way depending on the needs of the patient as perceived by medical, nursing and allied hospital staff, GPs and domiciliary nursing services.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Admitted and non-admitted patients presenting to the ED with a primary reason of atrial fibrillation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Age < 30 years; Inability to provide informed consent; Home address outside hospital catchment area; Absence of ECG documentation of AF during index admission; Patients with a terminal malignancy; Patients with end stage heart failure (NYHA class IV or LVEF < 20%); Cardiac surgery < 2 months prior to index admission; Documented thyrotoxicosis or pneumonia;

trial_design.concealment: Allocation of patients via a centralized web-based randomization schedule.
trial_design.sequence: Computer generated variable blocked (block sizes 4-8) randomization, with stratification per hospital

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common abnormal heart rhythm in the population and its prevalence is rapidly increasing. Sufferers of atrial fibrillation have a significantly impaired quality of life and their medical management is placing a growing burden on the Australian health care system. The proposed study will examine whether a home-based education program, will reduce hospital use and improve quality of life in AF patients compared to those patients who experience usual medical care.
